clean_story:
Stellar death. Cosmic rebirth.

The universe’s recycling system is how stars break down, scatter, and rebuild the same atoms—like a giant factory that never wastes raw materials.

Stars are cosmic furnaces. They fuse hydrogen into helium, then heavier elements—carbon, oxygen, iron—until they collapse or explode.

A supernova (like the one that formed the Crab Nebula in 1054) blasts these elements into space at 30,000 km/s, seeding new star systems.

Your bones’ calcium? Forged in a dying star. The gold in your phone? Likely from neutron star collisions, where two ultra-dense cores merge and spray heavy metals across galaxies.

Even black holes recycle. Their jets of energy heat surrounding gas, slowing star formation but also stirring clouds into future suns.

The Milky Way recycles 3 sun-masses of gas per year—enough to birth new stars while leaving traces of the old.

Planetary nebulae (like the Helix Nebula) are gentler recyclers: a sun-like star’s outer layers drift away, exposing its core while enriching space with nitrogen and carbon.

Every atom in your body has been through at least one star’s life cycle. Some, like iron, survived supernovae. Others, like hydrogen, have been recycled since the Big Bang.

Dust grains in meteorites (like those in the Murchison meteorite) contain presolar stardust—tiny time capsules from stars that died before our solar system formed.

Nuclear fusion’s limits. Galactic winds. The first molecules after the Big Bang.
